Évaluation publiée le 25 septembre 2017
Vidéo YouTube™: Xing: The Land Beyond game play and commentary 
Vues : 108
Some gameplay of Xing,.. Zing? Ex ing? Crossing?? not sure really..


This is yet another game where I wish I had a yes and no option for recommendation. Xing is puzzle game. Kind of. Let's just start out with the good. Graphically it's mostly good. I downloaded this game the day it released because I was really looking forward to a Myst style adventure. When I fist lauched it and the menu area came up my first reaction was, "wow,.. this looks like poo." it was super blurry and jagged around the edges, like many games I've seen where they look great in the screen shots and the clips but in actual VR, not so much. Then I looked at the settings and they were all on low (probably due to the beefy computer you need to run this game) so I maxed them all out which did help quite a bit but still the game was pretty blurry. So I decided to wait to play and review and make a recommendation in the disscussions that the game needed optimization. The dev responded and it sounded like he/she just didn't have any more ideas on how to improve the graphics and really, I can see that. This game does a ton graphically. lots of motion. details like the trees blowing in the wind and the water and reflections of water on the rocks and such make it very demanding. I set my super sampling to 3, still blurry. not terrible mind you but enough to make me constantly wish it was better. There were so many people complaining about the blurriness and performance issues in Obduction (which I loved) so I went back and checked it out to see If I just didn't remember it correctly. Nope this is def not nearly as sharp as Obduction is. It does however seem to perfom better.

The puzzle element is where I go to sleep on this one. I have read in other reviews that they get harder as you go,. but from the 60 minutes or so I did play, they were spoon fed to me. I think that is one of the things that just bugs me about Xing. everything is just kind of placed right there. The level design feels ,.. I don't even know how to describe it,. almost like an after thought. There is just stuff kind of scattered everywhere,. but it's all right there for you,. a birdbath that tells you you need fire next to a fence with vines that clearly need to be burned then another very close by birdbath that gives you a poem about needing fire and low an behold it's right next to a fire pit. I'm not feeling like things are really going to get to taxing in this game. Myst it is not for sure.

Game play itself,. the locomotion is great. I'm surprised there isn't a teleport option. personally if I was developing I would include one because there are so many people that can't handle the smooth locomotion. It's the point your controller type loco which I love. runs really smooth and didn't cause any frame rate drops. the motion controllers work just as they should. There is some jump mechanics that did end up frustrating me to the point of quitting for now but otherwise gameplay is solid.

Sound,. here is one of the things that just kills this game for me. The God awful music. I would much rather have a game where the music is very minimally used. maybe to emphasize an important event or area you have entered,.. but this music mostly plays on a loop over and over and it is just terrible. Very corny ochestral soap opera type music. I feel like this kind of thing really distracts you from being immersed in the world rather than pull you into it.

So I am going to be the one with the unpopular opinion of Xing and say that if you are wanting a great, engaging, deep puzzler this is not going to scratch your itch. If you want a simple somewhat pretty game to stroll along a beach in and follow extremely clear cut solution puzzles,.. then have at it.

Évaluation publiée le 26 septembre 2017
Got about 5 hours under my belt and just started the 3rd world. I'm really enjoying this game. I'm not having any issues with graphics or performance. I've tweaked a lot of settings and I have a high-end PC, so YMMV.

I'd have to say that this is a very laid back and chill puzzle game. It's mostly about the atmosphere and the spoon-fed poetic story snipets along the way. There's something almost Zen about it. It's not very deep and the puzzles start out very straight-forward. It does increase in difficulty as you go, but not a whole lot that it's going to frustrate you. If you are familiar with The Witness, this is NOT anything like that. The puzzle complexity and more open world setting of The Witness is a much bigger challenge. But that's ok. Xing is like a themepark with enough environmental puzzles to make the scenery more enjoyable.

Someone complained about the background music. I found it soothing, but there is an option to turn the volume of the music down/off, so if it bugs you, there is that option. And then maybe play your own.

Personally, I'm glad that they chose the locomotion method that they did. I don't suffer from VR sickness at all, and I find the experience of moving through the world of Xing nice and relaxing. I like the method for interacting with objects. I often play seated, with player height raised via OpenVR Advanced Settings. I was worried that I wouldn't be able to reach certain objects, but the game mechanic makes it super easy.

All in all, it has made for the type of VR experience that I really dig.

Évaluation publiée le 19 novembre 2017
I am not one for writing reviews. But this is simply the most beautiful "adventure" game I've ever played on my PC. If you've got the ability to max out settings, it's simply stunning to look at. And the good thing is: there are so many settings one can tweak, it SHOULD play on any PC.
Pros: everything, really:
The graphical presentation of all the environments (day with clouds and sun dappling or streaming,night,the night sky and the cosmos...towards the ending especially...waterfalls, brooks,rivers,desert sand and windstroms,snow and snow storms,ice,rain...goodness;every environment known to man is presented here beautifully). A marvel to behold: every single chapter's visuals.
The musical score: despite some repitition during individual chapters once the chapter "theme" has run out,so to speak, the music is so wonderful to listen to so the SLIGHT repition didn't bother me one bit. The scores (and there are a lot of musics for each chapter and area in the game) are deep,lush,majestic,haunting. Think "big movie music",folks. The desert chapter might have been the best score for any area in any game I've ever heard.
The stories (different "lives", or stories, to cover in each chapter and then a whole bunch more in the gated/main area once you've completed a chapter or two) are wonderfullly presented as you move about. Deep,rich, poetic stories. Even the "mini stories" detailing "past lives" in the gated area off the main area before you plunge into each of the 5 chapters. Make SURE you visit them, as they aren't needed to complete the game.
--I was going to slightly nudge toward "♥♥♥♥" for the morass of puzzles...and Lord knows there are a LOT...seemingly endless, BUT: you feel absolutely rewarded for everything you solve along the way,as you progress towards the end of each chapter. Some puzzles give you a nudge forward, and perhaps those with bigger puzzle-solving power than me can progress more quickly. A few are easy, but they all are logical, so there's that. Nothing mind-bending. Well, not really :-)
And, there are some great video walkthroughs online to help you along. I had to access them a few times, but once I peeked at each of the several solutions needed, I thought to myself: "why didn't I SEE that?" So, like I said; someone better at these things would not have a hard a time with SOME of the voluminous puzzle-solving as I did at times.
Game auto saves from where you left off if you need to quit out and play again later. ANd each chapter can be revisited once completed,too. I know I will replay some just to soak in the visuals tand the music.
So, there you go.
A beautiful, majestic game. Outstanding: an emotional experience to view, involve yourself in, and to listen to AS you're playing.
10/10 even with the somewhat hard time I had solving things here and there. Worth the price point as it gives you the ability to re-visit an area (one or all) once each chapter is completed. I can't see how this won't give a PC gamer many hours of enjoyment.
I hope this team continues to produce games this outstanding!

Produit reçu gratuitement

Xing the Land Beyond is a beautiful puzzle title that is being guided by the player itself. In the end it’s up to you if you want to relive the story of the forgotten. The game’s envoirements, creative puzzles and day and night cycle make it a very magical experience in VR. The developers made sure that all the challenges are close together so there is never really a moment of dullness.

You simply get rewarded in a satisfying way. Since there is no time clock ticking in the background it’s a relaxing journey that lets you appreciate VR even more. It also seems like they have nailed the locomotion especially the jumping works surprisingly well with Vive and Rift. Xing offers a lot of content. I can tell you that a decent amount of playtime in a VR game is rare nowadays but this puzzle game does not disappoint.

They came a long way. From a simple DK1 demo to a full game with amazing graphics, fresh gameplay and a story that keeps you playing.

XING: The Land Beyond ist nicht ganz das was ich erwartet hatte und es braucht dringend ein Update. Das das Video ruckelt lag leider an meinem System welches absolut an die Grenze gekommen ist ;-)...



Spielerlebnis (VR Version):
Am besten schaut ihr euch das Video oben mal an, das zeigt einen ersten Eindruck vom Spiel.
Leider wurden mein Erwartungen zu diesem Spiel in der momentanen Version noch stark getrübt. Trotzdem, ich gebe dem Spiel einen Daumen nach oben, weil die meisten Probleme technischer Natur sind und der Entwickler bereits eine schnelle Lösung versprochen hat.
XING: The Land Beyond ist ein Adventure / Rätsel Spiel mit einer etwas speziellen und schrägen Story.
Die Steuerung ist noch sehr unflexibel und fix Vorgegeben.
Die grossen Probleme mit der Grafik haben mich davon abgehalten das Spiel länger als eine halbe Stunde zu spielen.
Sobald das Spiel ein Update erhalten hat werde ich dieses Wunderschöne Adventure gerne weiter spielen.

*Wie man das Spiel scharf bekommt seht ihr im Video.


Bewegungsprofile:
Ihr könnt euch mit Room Scale in euerm Bereich frei bewegen.
Fortbewegung wird nur mittels flüssiger Bewegung angeboten.
(Teleport oder Step wird noch nicht angeboten)

Besonderheiten:
Extreme Grafik für VR

Pro:
- Volles Room Scale
- In Game Tutorial
- Sehr schöne Grafik
- Schöne Atmosphäre




Kontra:
- Benötigt extrem viel Leistung
- Nur eine Fortbewegungsmethode



In aktueller Version gut spielbar?:
Nach dem Aktuellen Update spielt sich das Spiel ganz gut.

Wünsche:
Erfüllt. Update ist erschienen.

Gespielt mit:

Intel I7 7700K
GTX 1080Ti
16GB Ram




wishes:
Please use the great level design for a game. The currently offered "game" is probably nothing at all.


Played with:

Intel I7 7700K
GTX 1080Ti
16GB Ram

MANY times i had to reply through levels i had mostly completed because i got stuck in the ground and couldnt move. i only found out after that if instead of restarting level you go to the main menu and reload it puts you back but still i shouldnt have to work that out and that was after having my time wasted.

i want to recommend this but this and other bugs made the game frustrating instead of satisfying.

i think trying to make this game VR and non VR friendly makes it fail in both(although i havent tried VR maybe its fine) the controls are incredibly clunky and i had to turn on jump assist to make it even playable and im not bad at platforming but these segments arnt supposed to be challenging they just fail because the controls are so clunky.

i also dont like how you interact with the world, because it has to work in VR you can only really walk around and throw things. throwing things doesnt feel particularly great either i often found the item didnt go where the aim assist said it would causing me to retry solved puzzles many times just to input the solution. i also dont like that holding an object almost completely blocks your vision. maybe in VR it wouldnt because it would be in my hand and not glued to my face but i didnt play in VR and this game is not VR only.

speaking of not being able to see the mechanic of swapping to night and day and having the world change is nice and all but i found it was hard to see in the dark making me bias towards one world state which made some puzzles more frustrating than they needed to be.

and perhaps the worst part of this game is the puzzle solutions themselves. some puzzles are literally just trial and error (the game even says thats what you are supposed to do) and the vast majority of puzzles are solved in your mind very quickly but you then have to spend a good amount of time slowly walking around and changing world state to actually input the solution making it feel more like a chore than a puzzle.

Also the game at one point introduces a massive red herring into the puzzle where the correct solution is to ignore half the puzzle elements and instead reach the goal by standing on a rising gong to get to the end instead. at first i thought i had broken the game or something but looking at a guide this is the intended solution (or atleast the real solution is so obscure that breaking the game is actually easier)

all in all a fairly frustrating game which is a shame because it has some nice ideas and i think if the devs had focused less on vr and the game being pretty the would have had more freedom to design a game thats less frustrating

Roughly halfway through (2/4 zones & 4 of the extra stories - took around 4 hrs so far) and really impressed by the design of levels and the puzzles within them - some challenge but logical and rewarding to figure out. Most of the game so far comes across polished and the voice acting is well done. Graphics settings are plentiful by the way - oversampling is there, on 100% by default which is a little blurry but up to 140-150% and every thing looks pretty sharp (of course with some impact on performance, but still very playable).

Évaluation publiée le 28 juin 2019
Produit reçu gratuitement

Follow "First Person Exploration and Puzzle Games" for more games like this!
Note: I only played this game without VR.

Pros
• The atmosphere in this game is amazing. Everything - from the mapping to the models to the animations, from the ambient audio to the music - is teeming with quality. It's honestly better than most AAA games in that regard.

Neutral
• The story is told through rhyming poems. It didn't seem terribly interesting or important.

• The game is extremely linear. Despite what other reviews say, this is not a Myst-like (where you explore freely and can do puzzles out-of-order).

♥♥♥♥
• The game suffers from some serious performance issues. Even with a GTX 980 TI, I had to turn the graphics down to medium, and even then I barely got 100 fps at 1080p. There were constant stutters and framedrops. I'd be worried to try this in VR.

• The puzzles (the meat of the game) are easy, even the bonus objectives. I didn't have to stop and consider what to do even once. Granted, I only got halfway through world 2, so it's possible they get more interesting later on.

Overall
I think if you're looking for a challenging puzzle game ala The Witness or The Talos Principle, you should look elsewhere. However if you want to relax with an extremely immersive and visually-pleasing puzzle game (possibly in VR), this game is a fantastic pick.

0.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 septembre 2017
Disclaimer: I worked for a few months on this title, helping to fix bugs and whatnot. So, there's some level of bias. But I'll try to be as objective as possible, for the sake of you, my dear reader.

XING: The Land Beyond is a slow game. That isn't to say it's poorly paced, or boring, but it's a game that encourages you to take your time, explore the environment, and enjoy the feeling of being in the game world...one especially enhanced by being in VR, if that's your thing. There are puzzles, and they get pretty moderately challenging by the end...but it's not like The Talos Principal, where the *focus* is on mind-bendingly difficult challenges.

The game is a visual and aural treat, and it's meant to be explored at leisure. It's very Myst-like, in many ways, though notably more guided, and less frustrating. If you're feeling stressed, want to get away from things, and relax in a beautiful world, this is your title. If you want a more action-based experience, or think games like Stephen's Sausage Roll or Recursed are too easy for you, it might be a pass. But for those willing, there's a pretty beautiful experience to be had, here.

Anyway, have fun! I (and all the full-time guys at White Lotus) are quite proud of the game. Good luck!

XING: The Land Beyond is a first person VR friendly puzzle/adventure game/walking simulator as you negotiate various casual puzzles in the afterlife, punctuated with a series of short narratives. There's a lightweight platformer element.

Tremendous visuals and a chill sound track round out a well polished and enjoyable puzzle adventure game. The price is a little high but the game appears in bundles and is discounted from time to time and should be considered for fans of this genre.

12.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 décembre 2023
Un jeu de casse-têtes sympa à la difficulté bien dosée, qui suit le destin tragique de plusieurs personnages à travers de courts poèmes à trouver sur le chamin.
Il faut dire qu'il n'y a pas beaucoup de meilleurs jeux dans la catégorie une fois qu'on a terminé la série des Myst. Si vous avez aimé Thalos Principle, c'est du même style. Chaque énigme ouvre une porte vers la prochaine énigme, qui est une variante du même mécanisme. Chacun des 4 mondes a son mécanisme (jour/nuit, niveau d'eau, gel, vent).

Les plus :
- ambiance agréable, poétique, jolis décors
- le niveau de difficulté fait réfléchir sans jamais bloquer longtemps la progression

Les moins :
- il faut maintenir Shift pour avancer à la vitesse normale (mais toujours pas rapide). Tout le jeu.
- ressemble plus à un Thalos Principle qu'à un Myst : plutôt que d'intéragir avec l'environnement, on pousse des blocs artificiels sans se demander pourquoi ils sont là
- platforming frustrant malgré l'activation de l'aide au saut. Je ne joue pas à ce genre de jeu pour essayer 8x de sauter par-dessus le même petit espace entre plates-formes, quand tomber signifie refaire une partie du puzzle
- facile de se soft-lock en s'aventurant dans le décor - m'est arrivé après 1 min de jeu, et plusieurs fois ensuite. Heureusement quitter et recharger la sauvegarde nous remet dans une position viable sans perte de progrès

Played in VR with a HP Reverb G2. This game's main appeal to me comes from its meditative, tranquil atmosphere and gorgeous, varied environments. Forests, deserts, tundras, temples, pagodas. I frequently found myself pausing just to look around and soak in the scenery. The game isn't really story-heavy, but does have story threads in every level with melancholy accounts of people's lives as they head towards the afterlife.

Gameplay-wise, the puzzles start off very easy but do get pretty devious towards the end. The gameplay is secondary to me in this title, though. As aforementioned, what this game really does well is atmosphere, and for that reason I found that I enjoyed it more than Talos Principle or Obduction in VR.

14.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 décembre 2021
Stumbled across this game as part of a bundle and I'm incredibly glad that I did. I'm a huge fan of the Myst/Riven type adventure game and I found XING to be an incredibly enjoyable experience. My entire play through took just under 15 hours and I played the entire game in VR.

You'll really enjoy this title if you like: puzzle games, beautiful environments, a moving if not somewhat abstractly told story-line, and impressive sound design/music score.

After finishing the game I was somewhat sad to see that this is the only game that White Lotus Interactive has apparently released. It's a shame. There's a LOT to like here. Even if there are a few glitches that aren't game breaking (I encountered a few, very minor graphics issues that I think 90 percent of people won't notice. There was one issue with some fonts on some in-game signage that wasn't important to the plot/puzzle progression too. This happened very late in the game.) Some of the music can get a little repetitive if you're stuck in a particular area, but overall it's wonderfully done.

This is one of the few VR games I'd actually recommend at full price. It's worth the journey into your headset, and the environments make wonderful places to mediate in.

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
210.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 janvier 2022
When you begin this game you have passed away and entered an afterlife of beautiful scenery and challenging adventure. There will be no rest here however, because you will be exploring a serene and beautiful beach, a beautiful lake area, a rain forest and a desert unlike any you have ever seen. You will meet a large stone being who will introduce you to the four souls whose lands you will visit.
Not only will you be exploring, you will be facing puzzles unlike any you have ever solved before. You will be able to make it rain, snow and become windy, and all of these changes will assist you in accomplishing an essential task. There will be jumps and precarious walks to make and if you fall the game will rescue you and place you right back to where you started. You will retrieve Runes from places impossible to reach (until you figure out how to get there) and throughout your experience you will listen to stories told by those who inhabited these beautiful lands.
I particularly enjoyed the beautiful soundtrack which somehow made it all worthwhile. There were also interesting sounds made when you accomplished a step in the puzzle.
You can have more than one game going at once and can spend hours enjoying each one. At the end there is a final level to each game called the "Steps of Akasha" which is probably the most challenging of all.
The controls are mouse and keyboard, no point and click, just free movement.
It is a truly beautiful game unlike any I have ever played! It has my full recommendation! Enjoy!

Wow.

Just wow.

Only an hour in, sure, but that hour had me captivated like no other VR game I've played to date. I literally felt like it was my first time playing video games, even though I've been gaming consistently for over 15 years. To me, this is what VR was made for..

This game took me to a very special place, and I can't wait to dive back in tomorrow. 10/10 would recommend.

24.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 avril 2020
Xing is an adventure/puzzle game about breaking your character's cycle of reincarnation. It's a very similar premise to another adventure game called The Wild Eternal, but Xing is much more gameplay-focused.

I bought the game because I was looking for an adventure/puzzle game that supported virtual reality. Xing's VR support is extremely good, and the game's gorgeous environments are best appreciated when you are fully immersed within them.

The puzzle mechanics in Xing are mostly environmental, including fantastical feats of wizardry such as manipulating the weather, time of day, and direction of the wind. Puzzles are usually easy to moderate difficulty, and even the more complicated-looking puzzles are actually simpler than they seem. My nemesis were the block sliding on ice puzzles, and one of those puzzles to get an optional rune on the third level was the one-and-only time I threw up my hands and looked up the solution.

After completing the four main levels, I was pleasantly surprised to see that there were additional small levels that were basically short-stories of other past-lives. They didn't have any puzzles and amounted to "walking simulator" sections, but the environments were unique and gorgeous to behold in VR.

I experienced a few bugs in my playthrough, including one bug that froze my character in mid-air above a fan. I couldn't do anything, not even open the menu, so I had to Alt-F4 out of the game.

The bug that really has me frustrated was with Steam achievements. In the session of Xing where I first completed the game, I didn't get any achievements. My three remaining achievements are "Hidden," but I assume one of them has to be for completing the fifth level and finishing the game. I replayed the 5th level TWICE trying to earn more achievements, including reloading a backup save file from a few days ago. I could not get a perfect game. 😭

EDIT: I found out that the three remaining achievements were for two short-stories and a unique secret item I'd missed. For some reason, all of Xing's achievements are hidden, so I had to do some searching to figure out what I'd missed. Bizarrely, there are no achievements associated with actually completing the final level of the game! I got the three achievements and earned my 25/25 perfect game.

Xing is a well-designed, generally polished game that should be held in high regard. I have massive respect for the extremely small team of developers that made this ambitious game a reality.

Évaluation publiée le 21 décembre 2019
Experienced on Valve Index.

Recommended.

Very good full-length puzzle game for VR. Highly recommended if you're looking for a more meaty adventure/puzzle game in VR to sink your teeth into. I collected all of the runes and found some of the puzzles to be a good challenge but nothing insanely difficult. I quite enjoyed the little backdrop stories as well.

A few comments/issues for cconsideration
1) It doesn't seem made "for VR". This is not necessarily a bad thing, and is obviously a plus if you don't have a VR setup, but it also means the puzzles are not enhanced by VR in any way.

2) (Unsurprisingly) I had to compromise on the graphics to get it to run smoothly (1080TI). It looked ok, even good, but I really wish I could have experienced it in full glory in VR. VR is very demanding, but it also feels poorly optimized compared to other good looking VR games I've played.

3) I dunno what was going on with the movement options--possibly specific to Index?--but fiddling around with several of the movement options seemed to do nothing at all, so I was stuck with the defaults. I got used to it, but it wasn't my preference. I don't mind sliding movement at all, but I couldn't get turning to work how I wanted, and I would've preferred if the movement thumbstick could be moved in different directions for relative movement.

4) Sometimes the jump assist didn't work as intended. I wanted to jump to the next block but there'd be something behind me and I'd jump backward to that instead. I didn't experience this later in the game so I'm not sure if it was patched, or if that issue was unique to early on.

Évaluation publiée le 30 aout 2019
Loved it in VR!
Well-optimized graphics, natural locomotion, beautiful environments, tons of content, no long loading screens. Played fine on my Radeon RX 580 with all the graphics settings at their max.

Every time I thought the game was over, I'd turn the corner to another epic level. The weather effects were really amazing, as were the day/night transitions, water, and lighting. The VR support on the Rift (both S and CV1) was great. No teleport option, but the locomotion was easy to use, with no motion sickness (occasionally a problem for me). Only a few of the puzzles were extremely tough, but I felt that most were just about right to keep things challenging without slowing the pace too much. Besides, I'd rather look at all the breathtaking scenery than get stuck in a corner doing math or something- and there was a lot of breathtaking scenery! The game had a true open-world feel to it. Barriers rarely felt unnatural or contrived. I was pleasantly surprised by all the nooks and crannies I could explore. I also love that I can continue to return to the environments after beating the game.

I just finished playing another game by a more established team in this genre and, while very impressive, I have to admit that Xing did a much better job of delivering a solid VR experience. If you are looking for a VR puzzle/exploration game, Xing is top-notch.

19.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 juillet 2019
Lavish, relaxing, and challenging. This is another successful star in the constellation of Myst-inspired adventure games. Respectfully shameless borrowing from Talos, Portal, and even Antichamber blends with original elements to be exactly What You Were Looking For when you searched for more of what those games did best. The puzzles ramp up in complexity gradually, keeping play in the perfect challenge/reward channel that holds interest while avoiding either boredom or frustration. In an important departure from most games that manage to do that, this one doesn't just make the later puzzles more complex. They do get harder, but a lot of the unlocking you do towards the end requires making sense of the setting as much as it requires figuring out the solution. That is, the environment is so rich with vegetation, structures, pathways, etc., that you will sometimes feel a bit overwhelmed at first encounter with a new puzzle. But, walking around and taking stock of what's there will let you grasp each such situation fairly quickly. This becomes a significant part of how you'll solve the most complex problems in the latter part of the game and it adds a lot to your sense of satisfaction. You're not just coping with a long series of logic problems. Instead, you're exploring your situation, learning what you need to know, and then dealing with what's around you. We liked that.

Now, the developers have said they are coping with marketing problems. At the same time, they seem to think that a lot of those problems arise from us non-VR players thinking this game is only for VR, while their marketing materials seem to emphasize almost nothing but VR. I wish they'd stop doing that, but it seems they are deep into some kind of relationship with Sony and the PS/4, so maybe Sony is to blame for the over-emphasis on VR. Whatever the reason, let me be as clear as I can on this:

THIS GAME IS GREAT WITHOUT VR!

If like you liked Myst, Talos, Eyes of Ara, Myha, or any of the other adherents to the first-person wandering walking-sim religion, this is for you.

Recommandé
27.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 octobre 2018
This is the most beautifully created game I've ever played. Sometimes I just walk to a place and compose an image with the controls, as if I were to take a photo of the scene. The amount of detail and taste that went into the creation of the worlds is just staggering.

This games creates the kind of awe and wonderment I had when I first played "Myst". Playing "XING: The Land Beyond" is truly an experience.

The puzzles aren't hard so "XING" is not the best choice for hardcore puzzle fans. They get a bit tougher towards the end, but never become very difficult. The puzzles fit in very well with the worlds and I believe it is by design that they don't hinder progress through these calm and serene worlds too much.

If only "Obduction" had the incredibly good aesthetics of "XING" and had received the same level of attention, it would have been a ton more enjoyable. The art direction and accomplished designs of "XING" with a "Quern"/"Myst"/"Riven"-type puzzles would be an adventurer's dream. Note, though that the moderate puzzle difficulty shouldn't detract from the fantastic quality of "XING", which just targets a slightly different genre than full-on puzzle games.

If I had to mention a tiny quibble, I'd mention the jump mechanics. I got used to them but still now and then missed a jump which can be frustrating. I noticed the jump assist option but felt that the foot markers took away some of the immersion, so I played without the assist and managed fine. I'm also a big fan of puzzles that are an integral part of the environment. "XING" handles this very well, overall, but for instance the moving blocks do not appear to make sense outside being part of an obstacle to master. I would have preferred completly natural and organically integrated puzzles, such as getting a ship to sail, using just normal materials and tools.

I wholeheartedly recommend "XING". It is an astounding accomplishment in game design and an absolute joy to play.

P.S.: I played without a VR headset and am grateful that this option exists. Even without a VR headset, it was a wonderful immersive experience.

I'm happy I kickstarted this one!

Évaluation publiée le 5 décembre 2017
Produit reçu gratuitement

XING is a game me and my colleagues in NEXT TV Bulgaria (when it was still active as a T Vshow) expected with much interest. It was a very promising project I couldn't stop checking on.
Having received this game at its release, I couldn't have been happier.

The graphics:
Xing's graphics are a pleasure to the eye. The bright neon colours match perfectly in the environment created by the makers. Every screenshot you take would be a great desktop, if you allow me to make this reference ;)

The gameplay
I have most negatives to say aboutu the mechanics of the game, but they are not really gamebreaking nonetheless.
However, if you are a nervous player like me and don't see the point of replaying if the game let you move a piece so far so that the only option forth is reloading form last save game...
Another issue I eoncountered is that the puzzles are repettiive. pleasant, brain-training, but repatitive. I would have liked less instances of puzzles to be in the game than be as repetitive.

Story
Loved the stories, the pieces of information, the voices, the sounds, the tiny monumental links between the characters and the worlds.


Overall gaming experience: 8.5/10 considering this is a mainly puzzle game and not a story-filled adventure.

15.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 novembre 2017
VR Review:

Stuff I Loved:

Wondering around overgrown Aztec-style architecture and pushing puzzle pieces to the correct conclusion feels like something VR was made for. The scale of the locations, the soft awe of the larger elemental shifts, the ability to size up and pace around the physical puzzles laid out before you... these things all really fall into place here. The game totally gets this, and chooses to focus on getting you into a state of quiet contemplation as you move around the environments and individual puzzle zones. It often excels at it, making this a very zen game indeed.

The puzzle motifs are built around finding the right environmental settings (night/day, stormy/dry etc) to allow items to be manipulated and progressed, often involving a throw or set of jumps to be executed along the way. While never getting deeply fiendish or completely fantastical, both the puzzle difficulty and atmospheric endeavour ramp up after a fairly anodyne and easy first map. The core elements slowly layering up in a pretty satisfying fashion, occasionally getting their own twists and tweaks, and taking place in a surprising number of locations by the end too.

Some Downsides:

I'll be honest, I wasn't a huge fan of the rhyming couplets used to tell the story strands for each area, or the music (which I turned off), but I found enough personality in the locations, and suitable soundscapes from the item interaction and nature noises, that I felt no big loss at zoning them out.

The only issue that really bugged me was when apprently well-timed jumps didn't execute. (As in physically passing through the object you're aiming for). I'm assuming that a central standing location was taken as a reference point and I'd strayed too far from it on those occasions.

The slowww walk speed also suited the tone but would would have benefited from a sprint option at times. There's a fair bit of back and forth as you flip environmental settings and enact your theories. (Combine this with the odd glitched jump that had no convenient reset and it did start to get counter-zen at times...). But ultimately I can see why it was chosen.


Overall:

That's 15 hours of super-chilled unwinding for £15. Which makes this one of the best bang-for-buck VR titles I've played to date. And those hours bore many hallmarks of thoughtful quality along the way which belie the game's indie origins :)

Edit: Bonus Video:

*Video Link*

Just a quiet moment I grabbed. The water reflections on the rock arc had transfixed me for a bit. Think the clip highlights the super chilled vibe that the environments and puzzles encourage. (Had to boost the sound a bit as it seemed quieter than I remember, but it's possible it is pretty passive. No real spoilers and no mechanics used although a late -game puzzle zone shown)
